title: Introduction to xafty
text: create network object, call xafty::init_network(). network object must least one project order start building network pipeline. project can added following: Projects multi-purpose structures used hold organize nodes, well encapsulate logic settings nodes treated within respective projects. setup need start building network. , process just like creating pipeline: need data transformation steps operate .
code: library(xafty) network <- init_network("intro_network") network$add_project("mtcars")

title: Introduction to xafty
text: Let’s add mtcars dataset network. , write function returns data.frame: start building network pipeline, register function mtcars project: Since function get_mtcars dependencies, automatically set root node project. Note: currently, xafty expects project one root node. can inspect project printing console query network desired variables:
code: get_mtcars <- function() {   data("mtcars", envir = environment())   mtcars }  head(get_mtcars()) #>                    mpg cyl disp  hp drat    wt  qsec vs am gear carb #> Mazda RX4         21.0   6  160 110 3.90 2.620 16.46  0  1    4    4 #> Mazda RX4 Wag     21.0   6  160 110 3.90 2.875 17.02  0  1    4    4 #> Datsun 710        22.8   4  108  93 3.85 2.320 18.61  1  1    4    1 #> Hornet 4 Drive    21.4   6  258 110 3.08 3.215 19.44  1  0    3    1 #> Hornet Sportabout 18.7   8  360 175 3.15 3.440 17.02  0  0    3    2 #> Valiant           18.1   6  225 105 2.76 3.460 20.22  1  0    3    1 network$mtcars$get(get_mtcars()) # Inspecting the network network #> Number of projects in network 'intro_network': 1 #>  #> Project: mtcars #> Variables: drat, vs, hp, am, disp, cyl, carb, mpg, qsec, wt, gear  # Wildcard selection returns all variables of a project mtcars <- nascent(network, query(mtcars = "*"))  # Querying variables by name will only return the desired variables data <- nascent(network, query(mtcars = c("carb", "gear"))) head(data) #>                   carb gear #> Mazda RX4            4    4 #> Mazda RX4 Wag        4    4 #> Datsun 710           1    4 #> Hornet 4 Drive       1    3 #> Hornet Sportabout    2    3 #> Valiant              1    3

title: Introduction to xafty
text: let network grow, simply query data need network, write step function transforms data, register function network: registering transformation step network, pass data directly function. Instead, declare required inputs using xafty::query. Internally, query resolved xafty::nascent() obtain actual data evaluate function’s return value, network can determine variables contributes. avoid recalculating entire data pipeline, can register function explicitly stating variables adds network using parameter vars: transformation step (e.g. function add_power_to_weight) xafty network written “pass-” function. function must satisfy following requirements: must refer variables name, column positions guaranteed. (function depends specific data structure rather just variable names, use objects instead.) must leave input data.frame unchanged return entire data.frame added transformation (embodied dplyr::mutate). necessary conditions make network pipelines possible connect larger vision: network pipeline, node represents self-contained transformation encapsulates knowledge derive specific outputs given inputs. Rather temporary, task-specific function, node defines reusable mapping data states, forming building block network’s directed acyclic graph. new patterns data emerge domain knowledge continues grow, nodes refined updated. envision network pipelines continuously evolving data structures captures preserves domain knowledge data analyst can express code.
code: # 1. retrieve data from the network data <- nascent(network, query(mtcars = c("hp", "wt")))  # 2. write the transformation step add_power_to_weight <- function(data) {   data$power_to_weight <- data$hp / data$wt   data }  # 3. register the step to the network network$mtcars$add(add_power_to_weight(data = query(mtcars = c("hp", "wt")))) network$mtcars$add(fun = add_power_to_weight(data = query(mtcars = c("hp", "wt"))),                     vars = "power_to_weight", update = TRUE) # Note: Setting update = TRUE prevents the network from asking # whether an already registered function should be updated.

title: Introduction to xafty
text: join two data sources, first need create second project another root node: join added network another transformation step. tell network wish register join passing two separate query-calls function: moment, joins treated symmetrical operations. result, network supports one join definition pair projects. Moreover, network assumes join performed projects appear first corresponding xafty::query() call. declare function depends join, register using single xafty::query() call includes least two different projects root nodes:
code: network$add_project("engine")  get_engine_details <- function() {   engine <- data.frame(     type = as.factor(c("Straight", "V-Shape")),     vs = c(1, 0)   )   engine }  network$engine$get(get_engine_details()) join_engine_details <- function(mtcars, engine) {   joined <- merge(mtcars, engine, by = "vs", all.x = TRUE, sort = FALSE)   joined }  network$engine$join(join_engine_details(mtcars = query(mtcars = "vs"),                                         engine = query(engine = "vs"))) add_combined_label <- function(data) {   data$combined_label <- paste(      data$type,       ifelse(data$am == 0, "Auto", "Manual"),       sep = "_"   )   data }  network$mtcars$add(add_combined_label(data = query(mtcars = "am", engine = "type")))

title: Introduction to xafty
text: many workflows, temporarily group data downstream transformations can operate group-level context. typical dplyr pipeline, simple calling group_by(), performing transformation, calling ungroup(). xafty network pipeline, however, grouping must declared explicitly. nodes independent assembled dynamically, grouping embedded inline within function. Instead, xafty lets define grouped execution contexts project level using entry exit hooks. project can automatically group data node entered ungroup node finishes, allowing transformation functions assume grouped input without containing grouping logic . start defining three pass-functions: Next, create new project use attach context : tell project apply grouping whenever data enters node: remove grouping node completes computation: Now, nodes registered per_gear inherit grouping behavior run. project may multiple on_entry() on_exit() functions. entry exit hooks applied order registered. allows us layer context-setting operations, grouping, arranging, reshaping, without embedding directly individual transformation functions.
code: library(dplyr, warn.conflicts = FALSE)  group_by_gear <- function(data) {   group_by(data, gear) }  ungroup_data <- function(data) {   ungroup(data) }  add_mean_hp_per_gear <- function(data) {   mutate(data, mean_hp_per_gear = mean(hp)) } network$add_project("per_gear") network$per_gear$on_entry(group_by_gear(data = query(mtcars = "gear"))) network$per_gear$on_exit(ungroup_data(data = "{.data}")) network$per_gear$add(add_mean_hp_per_gear(data = query(mtcars = "hp")))  data <- nascent(network, query(mtcars = c("gear"), per_gear = "mean_hp_per_gear"))  head(data) #> # A tibble: 6 × 2 #>    gear mean_hp_per_gear #>   <dbl>            <dbl> #> 1     4             89.5 #> 2     4             89.5 #> 3     4             89.5 #> 4     3            176.  #> 5     3            176.  #> 6     3            176.

title: Introduction to xafty
text: network grows, becomes increasingly important understand xafty assembles executes pipeline. Since nodes combined dynamically based variables request, xafty provides tools inspect resulting execution plan running . function build_dag() constructs directed acyclic graph given query returns list-object describes full pipeline:
code: dag <- build_dag(query(mtcars = c("gear"), per_gear = "mean_hp_per_gear", engine = "type"), network = network)   dag$execution_order #> [1] "mtcars.get_mtcars"             "engine.get_engine_details"     #> [3] "engine.join_engine_details"    "per_gear.group_by_gear"        #> [5] "per_gear.add_mean_hp_per_gear" "per_gear.ungroup_data"

title: Build Scalable Data Pipelines
text: Turn R data pipelines scalable collaborative network graph.

title: Build Scalable Data Pipelines
text: xafty turns data pipeline dependency graph instead linear script. step becomes reusable node declares needs provides. xafty resolves execution order , enables reuse across projects, hides complexity behind clean layers abstraction.

title: Build Scalable Data Pipelines
text: High flexibility overhead: Since node just function data.frame → data.frame, don’t adopt new data model rewrite existing logic. Existing code drops directly network minimal changes. Reduced cognitive burden: don’t need remember correct sequence function calls. Colleagues can retrieve data need without studying entire pipeline. simply query variables, xafty evaluates required steps. deciding variables needs, writing function takes returns data.frame, registering network. Effortless collaboration: Networks invite contribution. Dropping new node simple low-risk, unlike pipelines every change risks breaking flow.

title: Build Scalable Data Pipelines
text: data pipelines built one-scripts: hard reuse, fragile change, difficult teams collaborate . projects grow, leads duplicated logic, inconsistent results, constant need rebuild work already exists. xafty solves treating every transformation reusable node shared dependency graph. Instead rewriting steps every new project, teams compose pipelines existing, validated building blocks. makes data work reliable, maintainable, far easier extend time.

title: Build Scalable Data Pipelines
code: pak::pkg_install("davidcrone/xafty")

title: Build Scalable Data Pipelines
text: Diagram illustrating evolution single processing step chained branched network pipeline Let’s understand idea behind xafty going step step simple script network pipeline. Step 1: Stateful Pipeline Step 2: Functional Pipeline Step 3: Network Pipeline

title: Build Scalable Data Pipelines
text: Diagram illustrating stateful pipeline, “single purpose” block Probably everyone starting data analytics written data pipeline looked similar following: good start. gets point, fast comprehensible. codebase use-cases grow, several problems emerge: Hard reuse: Scripts linear stateful. colleague want part logic, need copy-paste code manually recreate upstream context. often breaks steps depend hidden side effects object states. Difficult scale: script grows, earlier steps become tightly coupled later ones. Small changes upstream can unintentionally cascade downstream, making pipeline fragile harder extend. Locked one use-case: linear script encodes single way run pipeline. later need different subsets data, alternative derivations, multiple outputs, entire script must restructured duplicated.
code: # 1. Load data data("mtcars")  # 2. Add derived variable mtcars$power_to_weight <- mtcars$hp / mtcars$wt  # 3. Get engine lookup table engine <- data.frame(   type = as.factor(c("Straight", "V-Shape")),   vs = c(1, 0) )  # 4. Join everything together mtcars <- merge(mtcars, engine, by = "vs", all.x = TRUE, sort = FALSE)  # 5. Use results plot(mtcars$type, mtcars$power_to_weight)

title: Build Scalable Data Pipelines
text: Diagram illustrating functional pipeline modularized linear structure, step cleanly seperated can address many shortcomings stateful script, writing everything function: already major improvement. modular structure makes pipeline composable, testable, reusable, much easier understand. approach modularizes logic, still needs assembled manually: Implicit dependency chains: function still relies called correct order. Dependencies remain implicit code flow, pipeline can break someone rearranges reuses functions without fully understanding upstream assumptions. Limited flexibility different outputs: need return slightly different subset data, produce multiple alternative outputs, end copying, commenting branching functions. pipeline becomes tangle custom assembly code instead reusable structure. Difficult reason impact: function modified, built-way ask: parts pipeline rely ? might change affect? Understanding ripple effects becomes manual error-prone process.
code: get_mtcars <- function() {   data("mtcars", envir = environment())   mtcars }  add_power_to_weight <- function(mtcars) {   mtcars$power_to_weight <- mtcars$hp / mtcars$wt   mtcars }  get_engine_details <- function() {   engine <- data.frame(     type = as.factor(c("Straight", "V-Shape")),     vs = c(1, 0)   )   engine }  join_engine_details <- function(mtcars, engine) {   joined <- merge(mtcars, engine, by = "vs", all.x = TRUE, sort = FALSE)   joined }  plot_mtcars <- function(mtcars) {  mtcars_plot <- plot(mtcars$type, mtcars$power_to_weight)  mtcars_plot }  # Assemble the pipeline mtcars_plot <- function() {  mtcars <- get_mtcars()  engine <- get_engine_details()    mtcars <- join_engine_details(mtcars = mtcars, engine = engine)  mtcars <- add_power_to_weight(mtcars = mtcars)    plot_mtcars(mtcars = mtcars) }  # Run the pipeline mtcars_plot()

title: Build Scalable Data Pipelines
text: Diagram illustrating network pipeline, step node connected according dependencies Moving functional pipeline network pipeline final step making code fully declarative, flexible, scalable. reuse functions step 2 express xafty network: xafty, function step 2 becomes node network. Instead passing data function, use xafty::query() declare input variables needed. order retrieve data network, simply tell xafty::nascent() variables want. xafty walks graph, resolves required nodes topological order, returns single data.frame containing precisely asked . example, use network query following variables: resulting pipeline can represented follows: Diagram illustrating “collapsed” pipeline xafty network ➜ Pipelines longer assembled manually. simply query data need let system orchestration. ➜ network pipelines, intermediate steps just accessible final data products. makes easy “branch ” intermediate steps reuse , rather starting blank slate, common many data analytics projects. Finally, add original plot network, now use “objects”: retrieve object network: finally allows us fully represent functional pipeline step 2 network pipeline.
code: ## Preparation:  # Make sure that the functions from step 2 are loaded into memory. ## /Preparation  library(xafty)  # Initialize the network with the desired structure xafty_network <- init_network("example_network", projects = c("mtcars", "engine"))  ## Register the functions in project "mtcars" ##  # The function `get_mtcars()` is registered as a root node in the project "mtcars". xafty_network$mtcars$get(get_mtcars())  # Instead of passing data to `add_power_to_weight`, we register a dependency using query() xafty_network$mtcars$add(add_power_to_weight(mtcars = query(mtcars = c("hp", "wt"))))  ## Register the function `get_engine_details()` in project "engine" ## xafty_network$engine$get(get_engine_details())  # Finally, we register the join between the two projects,  # by passing two separate queries to the respective parameters xafty_network$mtcars$join(join_engine_details(mtcars = query(mtcars = "vs"),                                               engine = query(engine = "vs")))  # Inspect the network xafty_network  # Pull data as needed from the network in the desired column order xafty_network |> nascent(mtcars = c("hp", "wt", "vs"),                           engine = "type",                           mtcars = "power_to_weight") xafty_network |> nascent(mtcars = "hp", engine = "type") # The add_object function allows us to register a function with any return value to our network xafty_network$mtcars$add_object("mtcars_plot",                                  plot_mtcars(mtcars = query(engine = "type",                                                             mtcars = "power_to_weight"))) # Write the object's name in squared brackets xafty_network |> nascent(mtcars = "[mtcars_plot]") # As of now, only a single object per query might be retrieved from the network

title: Build Scalable Data Pipelines
text: xafty still active development, find already quite feature rich: Programming states, passed alongside queries via xafty::with_state(). Context entry/exit project, similar dplyr::group_by() / ungroup(), enabling wrapping lossless transformations. Wildcard selection xafty::query(project = "*") request variables project. Inspection tools, xafty::build_dag(), view internal dependency graph.

title: Build Scalable Data Pipelines
text: Network-based pipelines open door many extensions integrations. overview near-term roadmap ambitious directions.

title: Build Scalable Data Pipelines
text: Version 1.0 aims make xafty practical solution ~95% everyday data-pipeline workflows. reach milestone, several essential features still need implemented: Support lossy transformations (e.g., dplyr::group_by() / summarise()), integrated seamlessly network structure flexible filtering mechanism using () clause, providing fine-grained control filtering applied Developer tooling, visualizations printable summaries network components, make building xafty easier Robust testing bug fixing ensure reliability scale

title: Build Scalable Data Pipelines
text: Beyond core roadmap, xafty can evolve powerful component within existing analytic ecosystems: Integration {targets}: DAG created via xafty::build_dag() translated directly {targets} pipeline, unlocking caching, parallel processing, full reproducibility Interoperability DuckDB Arrow: Allowing nodes backed SQL Python enable cross-language collaboration high-performance hybrid networks

title: Build Scalable Data Pipelines
text: xafty active development, feedback incredibly valuable! ’re curious, testing , ideas improve , want prioritize feature get touch open issue. Whether ’s bugs, feature requests, just chat, ’d love hear ! :)

title: Set or Change the Print Order of Projects — set_project_print_order
code: xafty_network <- init_network("change_order",                    projects = c("Project2", "Project1")) print(xafty_network) # Prints Project2 first, then Project1 #> Number of projects in network 'change_order': 2 #>  #> Project: Project2 #>  #> Project: Project1  # Change the print order set_project_print_order(   projects = c("Project2", "Project1"),   order = c(2, 1),   network = xafty_network ) print(xafty_network) #> Number of projects in network 'change_order': 2 #>  #> Project: Project1 #>  #> Project: Project2
